title: 107_s1942
content: The "Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002" is also known as the "Biodiesel Used as Fuel" section, which provides incentives for the use of biodiesel as a fuel. This Act amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to offer credits for businesses that use biodiesel. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a biodiesel fuels credit for businesses using biodiesel mixtures. The credit is based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons of the mixture used. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a credit for businesses using biodiesel mixtures, based on the biodiesel mixture rate and gallons used in qualified biodiesel mixtures sold or used in trade or business activities. Casual off-farm production is not eligible for the credit. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a credit for businesses using biodiesel mixtures, excluding casual off-farm production. The credit amount is adjusted to account for any benefits from excise tax exemptions. Biodiesel is defined as monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids from virgin vegetable oils for diesel engines. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a credit for businesses using biodiesel mixtures derived from various vegetable oils for diesel engines. The biodiesel must meet registration requirements set by the EPA and ASTM D6751. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers a credit for biodiesel mixtures used in diesel engines. If biodiesel is separated from the mixture or used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons. Applicable laws and penalties apply to this tax. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides a tax credit for biodiesel mixtures used in diesel engines. Applicable laws and penalties apply to the tax imposed on biodiesel mixtures. Taxpayers can elect to not apply for the tax credit for any taxable year. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 allows taxpayers to elect not to apply for the biodiesel fuels credit after December 31, 2012. The credit is treated as part of the general business credit, with no carryback of the credit before January 1, 2003. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 prohibits the carryback of the biodiesel fuels credit before January 1, 2003. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to reflect this change. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. The rate of tax for qualified biodiesel mixtures is reduced under specified regulations. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures. The tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures is reduced based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture. Definitions and rules from section 40A apply to this subsection. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 reduces motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures based on biodiesel percentage. Section 40A rules apply to define qualified biodiesel mixtures. Amendments to sections 4041 and 6427 of the Internal Revenue Code implement these changes. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 reduces motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures. The amendments specify that if diesel fuel is used to produce a qualified biodiesel mixture, the Secretary will pay an amount equal to the applicable biodiesel mixture rate. Transfers from the Commodity Credit Corporation will offset reductions in the Highway Trust Fund receipts due to these changes. Effective from December 31, 2002, to January 1, 2013.
